stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the level design and layout for the 'Oil Rig' stage. The stream focused heavily on brainstorming sessions for the level's boss fight, resulting in the 'Oil Blargg' and 'soap' mechanic. There were also discussions on the visual design of Bowser's office, updates to the game's lighting and fog, and Kaze's broader game design philosophies.

development_findings.summary: The team is in a 'polishing phase,' which includes updating visuals like fog and lighting, and completely remaking some of the older, smaller 'retro areas' to match the quality of newer levels.
A secret 'Magic Show' Easter egg is planned where players can find Bowser performing bad magic tricks and telling terrible jokes.
development_findings.quote: Basically Bowser has... it's an easter egg... you can enter Bowser's magic show and Bowser just sounds like a bunch of really bad jokes on there and does a few bad magic tricks and that's it.

development_findings.summary: The oil rig level, tentatively named 'Oozing Oil Operation,' will feature a central boss fight, platforming around a power generator, and a connected underwater area that functions as a quick-travel system between different parts of the level.
The team decided on a unique boss for the oil rig level: a Gargantua Blargg from Yoshi's Island made of oil.
development_findings.quote: I think the oil block is really our play here. Because blocks are really famous in Yoshi's Island. They're everywhere. And oil block just fits so well to this level.

development_findings.summary: The primary mechanic for the oil Blargg boss fight will involve the player riding on a bar of soap, chasing the boss to 'clean' it, which causes it to shrink and eventually be defeated.
development_findings.quote: You make him swallow soap? Is soap how you get rid of oil? ... Honestly, that sounds like a shitpost idea but at the same time, I kind of like it.

development_findings.summary: To solve performance issues and create a more dynamic fight, the oil boss will swallow Mario and spit him out into a separate, dedicated arena for the battle.
development_findings.quote: I think I eats you and spits you out in a separate area. Oh I like that. Yeah yeah alright let's do that fuck it.

development_findings.summary: A technical issue with the cannon's aiming reticle arose after Kaze updated the libultra libraries, requiring him to remake the reticle system from scratch.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works a full-time job as an Unreal Engine programmer at Gears for Breakfast, which limits his development time on the project. He estimates the game is two-thirds complete after nearly three years of work.
context_findings.quote: I do have a full-time job so I can't spend that much time on it. I'm trying to get it done in a timely manner but we are only two-thirds through the game and it's been like almost three years now.

context_findings.summary: The game's physics have been altered so significantly from the original Mario 64 that it requires players, especially speedrunners, to relearn the game's controls and movement.
context_findings.quote: The thing with this hack is that the physics are so different that you're going to unlearn your normal Mario 64 muscle memory. So if you are a speedrunner and you want to speedrun this game, you kind of have to commit to only speedrunning this game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a lack of concern about legal action from Nintendo, stating he has successfully contested their YouTube copyright claims in the past and believes making money is not their primary criteria for takedowns.
context_findings.quote: I don't think Nintendo gives a shit whether you make money from your mods or not... Last time they took me down, I told them to fuck off, basically, and they did fuck off. I'm even, like, contesting their YouTube claims and they're putting me back online. I'm not really that worried about Nintendo anymore.

context_findings.summary: Kaze criticizes Pikmin 2 for what he perceives as a lack of player freedom and meaningful choice, comparing the gameplay to being a 'worker drone' following instructions in randomly generated levels.
context_findings.quote: The promise with Pikmin 2 is that everything is kind of just like random AI generated dungeons and the game asks you to just beat all of them. And there's like nothing to it. You don't actually make any choices... You have no freedom. You're basically just like a worker drone.

context_findings.summary: Kaze adheres to a design principle of avoiding the overuse of custom mechanics that replace Mario's core moveset, believing that relying too heavily on them often results in lower-quality ROM hacks.
context_findings.quote: It's kind of one risk when you make a game like this because we have so many options it's very tempting to use our custom coding instead of the Mario moveset and I think that often leads to poor ROM hacks. So I want to avoid that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to release the game's source code, but only a week or two after the game's release to prevent spoilers and reduce potential legal trouble with Nintendo.

biobak.summary: Kaze states that Biobak reviews and refines his 3D models, which significantly improves their visual quality.
biobak.quote: My oh my couch a lot with the models he like whenever I finish a model he's looking over it again. It makes it a lot prettier.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a mock-up for a new area, demonstrating his involvement in the visual and environmental design process.
Biobak suggested the idea of the oil boss absorbing all the oil from the surrounding water when it forms, which Kaze immediately liked and decided to implement.
Biobak was responsible for the idea of adding horns to the design of Bowser's office building.
biobak.quote: Putting horns on the building. Yep, I think that was a very fun touch that Biobak had.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for character animations, including those for Bowser and NPCs like the Buzzy Beetles.
zeina.quote: Is there any more Bowser's animations that you need or can I send these off and work on the NPCs?

zeina.summary: Zeina is actively involved during streams, often helping Kaze with tasks and participating in design discussions off-mic.
zeina.quote: You never heard my wife's voice before? I guess she's often quiet in the background. I'm usually just helping him doing stuff.

zeina.summary: Zeina actively participates in brainstorming sessions, such as contributing ideas for the design and location of Bowser's castle on the oil rig.

key_stories.title: The Oil Blargg and the Soap Mechanic
key_stories.summary: The team collaboratively designed a boss for the oil rig level, starting with a need for a thematic enemy and evolving into a detailed concept. They settled on an oil-based version of a 'Blargg' from Yoshi's Island, defeated by a unique mechanic where the player chases it on a bar of soap to 'clean' it.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed a unique, thematically appropriate boss for the oil rig level that also felt connected to the game's 'Yoshi's Island' theme.
key_stories.process: The team brainstormed several ideas, rejecting standard Mario bosses like Boom Boom. Kaze pushed for a Yoshi's Island enemy, leading to the idea of a Blargg made of oil. This sparked a creative discussion about how to defeat it, moving from conventional ideas like fire to the unusual but fitting idea of soap. They then fleshed out the entire fight, including the arena, boss attacks, and how the player would use the soap mechanic.
key_stories.outcome: The team developed a complete concept for a boss fight against an oil-based Blargg. The fight involves a unique and playful mechanic where Mario rides a bar of soap to 'clean' the boss, causing it to shrink until defeated in a dedicated arena.
key_stories.key_quote: I was just thinking of like fire or like... you know, stuff like that. But soap? I don't know. ... Honestly, that sounds like a shitpost idea but at the same time, I kind of like it.

key_stories.title: Designing Bowser's Oil Rig Office
key_stories.summary: To avoid performance issues and design repetition, the team decided against a full Bowser's Castle on the oil rig. After debating several options, they settled on designing a tall, iconic office tower that is not explorable but contains visible Easter eggs, serving as a central landmark for the level.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to represent Bowser's headquarters on the oil rig without building a full castle, which would be resource-intensive and potentially feel repetitive.
key_stories.process: Initial ideas involved a castle embedded in a mountain, but Kaze was concerned about performance and the level feeling too small. The concept evolved into a large, enterable building, but this raised questions about what the player would do inside. After discussion, Kaze was convinced to pivot to a non-enterable tower, focusing on its exterior design and its role as a visual anchor for the level.
key_stories.outcome: The team decided against a traditional, explorable castle. Instead, they will create a tall, visually distinct office tower that serves as a landmark. Easter eggs inside the office will be visible from other parts of the level, solving performance concerns while still providing narrative detail.
key_stories.key_quote: I've also had the thought that it kind of sucks that this is another Bowser castle. I don't really want the whole castle. So I think I'm gonna go with that suggestion and just have it be a big tower.
